t: Proverbs 26
Like*pn snow in summer and rain at harvest, honor*ln is inappropriate for a fool.
Like*pn a flitting sparrow or a fluttering swallow, an*ln undeserved curse goes nowhere.
A*pn whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and*ln a rod for the backs of fools.
Don’t*ln answer a fool according to his foolishness or*ln you’ll be like him yourself.
Answer*ln a fool according to his foolishness or*ln he’ll become wise in his own eyes.
The*ln one who sends a message by a fool’s hand cuts*ln off his own feet and drinks violence.
A*ln proverb in the mouth of a fool is*ln like lame legs that hang limp.
Giving*ln honor to a fool is*ln like binding a stone in a sling.
A*ln proverb in the mouth of a fool is*ln like a stick with thorns, brandished*ln by the hand of a drunkard.
The*ln one who hires a fool or who hires those passing by is*ln like an archer who wounds everyone indiscriminately.
As*ln a dog returns to its vomit, so*ln also a fool repeats his foolishness.
Do*ln you see a person who is wise in his own eyes? There*ln is more hope for a fool than for him.
The*pn slacker says, “There’s a lion in the road — a*ln lion in the public square!”
A*ln door turns on its hinges, and*ln a slacker, on his bed.
The*ln slacker buries his hand in the bowl; he*ln is too weary to bring it to his mouth!
In*ln his own eyes, a slacker is wiser than*ln seven who can answer sensibly.
A*pn person who is passing by and meddles in a quarrel that’s not his is*ln like one who grabs a dog by the ears.
Like*ln a madman who throws flaming darts and deadly arrows,
so*ln is the person who deceives his neighbor and*ln says, “I was only joking!”
Without*pn wood, fire goes out; without*ln a gossip, conflict dies down.
As*ln charcoal for embers and wood for fire, so*ln is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.
A*ln gossip’s words are like choice food that*ln goes down to one’s innermost being.
Smooth*pn lips with an evil heart are*ln like glaze on an earthen vessel.
A*ln hateful person disguises himself with his speech and*ln harbors deceit within.
When*ln he speaks graciously, don’t believe him, for*ln there are seven detestable things in his heart.
Though*ln his hatred is concealed by deception, his*ln evil will be revealed in the assembly.
The*ln one who digs a pit will fall into it, and*ln whoever rolls a stone — it*ln will come back on him.
A*ln lying tongue hates those it crushes, and*ln a flattering mouth causes ruin.
